qas.question: What is one modality of being that Avicenna analyzed?
According to Avicenna, what could eventually be actualized by an external cause?
What is the necessary according to Avicenna?

answers.text: the source of its own being without borrowed existence

qas.question: According to Avicenna, what always exists?
If necessary being is true in itself, what is contingent?
What is one modality of being that Avicenna did not analyze?
Who argued that the impossible thing could exist?
What did Avicenna believe could never be actualized by an external cause?
What is the necessary not a source of?
What is one modality of being that Avicenna never analyzed?
According to Avicenna, what could eventually be actualized by an internal cause?

plausible_answers.text: the source of its own being without borrowed existence

qas.question: What is the unnecessary according to Avicenna?
According to Avicenna, what never exists?
If necessary being is false in itself, what is contingent?

context: Avicenna's consideration of the essence-attributes question may be elucidated in terms of his ontological analysis of the modalities of being; namely impossibility, contingency, and <a0_0><b5_0><b9_0>necessity<b9_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>. <b6_0>Avicenna<b6_0/> argued that the impossible being is that which cannot exist, while the <b7_0>contingent in itself<b7_0/> (mumkin bi-dhatihi) has the potentiality to be or not to be without entailing a contradiction. When actualized, the contingent becomes a 'necessary existent due to what is other than itself' (wajib al-wujud bi-ghayrihi). Thus, <a1_0><b10_0>contingency-in-itself<b10_0/><a1_0/> is potential beingness that could eventually be actualized by an external cause other than itself. The metaphysical structures of necessity and contingency are different. Necessary being due to itself (wajib al-wujud bi-dhatihi) is true in itself, while the contingent being is '<a4_0><b13_0>false in itself<b13_0/><a4_0/>' and 'true due to something else other than itself'. <a3_0><b12_0>The necessary<b12_0/><a3_0/> is <a2_0><b11_0>the source of <b8_0>its own being<b8_0/> without borrowed existence<b11_0/><a2_0/>. It is what always exists.
